 ii Loan and Project Summary Project Objectives and Description: The objectives are to : (a) provide a high-voltage transmission system rebuilt to meet an integrated system peak demand of approximately 1,500 MW at the N- I level of reliability ; and (b) assist GOL and EDL to implement the Action Program in their Letter of Sectoral Development Policy (LSDP) which provides for establishing and enabling environment for private sector involvement in the power sector, including the institutional restructuring of the sector. The proposed Project comprises two elements: (a) an investment component (US$480 million) which would include 339 km of double- and single-circuit 220-kV transmission lines, 49 km of underground 220-kV cables, and 14 new 220-kV substations; and (b) an institutional development component (US$6 million) consisting of technical assistance for the institutional reform action program defined in the LSDP. Benefits: The proposed Project would provide urgently needed transmission capacity without which EDL would be unable to deliver power from its new facilities. Eliminating rotating power cuts and the risk of unplanned blackouts have large indirect benefits as they prevent disruption to economic activity. Without these investments and the accompanying institutional reforms, the improvements in electricity supply recently achieved under the NERP would not be sustainable. The ability to provide reliable public supply will lead to the shutdown of small, inefficient private generators. The main economic benefit from the project is the incremental electricity demand served. There are also significant gains from the reduction in technical energy losses resulting from related investment in distribution. The institutional strengthening of EDL will re-establish sector analysis and planning. The proposed Project will also restore the operating ability of a restructured and financially sound EDL to manage the new transmission system. The financial recovery measures under the Project will put an end to reliance on operating subsidies from the national budget and permit self-financing of a portion of its investment program. Risks: The investment component of the proposed Project does not involve any unusual technical or environmental risks. Implementation will be on a turnkey basis, using prequalified international contracting firms. The Project includes an institutional strengthening component to reduce the risks of inadequate overall project management. The major risk facing the Project is political. Restructuring the sector and delegating the bulk of EDL's operations to the private sector is key to achieving the anticipated benefits earlier than under the status quo. Recruitment of private operators could be delayed or hindered because of political constraints and/or public opposition. In assessing the preceding risks, it is important to note that it is fully feasible, but not desirable, to continue EDL operations relying only on internal reforms rather than under the unbundled structure proposed under the proposed Project. Assuming however that given the political risks the govemment decides against restructuring EDL, the investment component would still be viable in that it would permit the power stations at Zaharani and Beddawi, currently under construction, to be connected to the transmission network. What would be lost is expected financial viability of EDL in the near term. This is an innovative project in the Lebanese context and the reform process may prove to be slower to implement than currently estimated. THE POWER SECTOR Background 1.1 Rebuilding and returning Lebanon's war-ravaged economy to sustainable growth involves three phases: (i) short-term emergency rehabilitation; (ii) medium-term reconstruction; and (iii) long-term expansion within the traditional market-based and outward-oriented policy framework. The phased- recovery program envisions that much of the reconstruction will be undertaken by the private sector. In accordance with this strategy, Lebanon embarked in late 1992 upon a three-year (1993-95), US$2.24 billion National Emergency Reconstruction Program (NERP). This initial program covered a series of high-impact rehabilitation investments, limited development of new facilities in priority areas, as well as institutional strengthening and technical assistance elements. The NERP is supported by US$225 million of Bank assistance through the Emergency Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Project (ERRP),' including a US$50 million supplement approved in May 1996, in the fields of power, water and waste water, solid waste, education, housing and telecommunications. Re-establishing institutional capacity in the power sector had not been specifically addressed under the NERP. Focusing attention on this aspect has now become critical. Energy Sector Context 1.2 Lebanon has no known fossil fuel resources. Apart from relatively modest hydroelectric resources and a newly-established power tie to Syria, all energy needs are met with imports of petroleum products, which exceeded 4.1 million tons in 1995 (Annex 1.1). The power sector accounts for about a third of fuel imports. There is considerable potential for use of solar energy, yet this source is virtually unexploited. Annex 1.2 contains an Energy Balance for 1994. Power Sector 1.3 Per capita electricity consumption, estimated at 1,460 kWh for 1995, is relatively high (see Figure I below) in comparison with other countries in the region. It reflects, in part, a proliferation of illegal connections during the 1980s and low tariffs. Consumption, however, is not out of line with non- regional countries at similar levels of per capita GDP. All villages have been electrified and virtually all households have access to electricity. Electricity is widely used for both water and space heating, partly due to the lack of access to alternative fuels, such as natural gas and solar heaters. There is also increasingly widespread use of air-conditioning, and system peak occurs in August. I Loan No. 3562-LE, 1993.

In particular, the transmission system was heavily damaged. Daily rotating blackouts have been routine since the late 1980s, with supply to consumers severely rationed, as only 500 MW to 600 MW of plant was operational versus a system demand of 1,100-1,300 MW. Most commercial and industrial customers and a significant proportion of residential consumers installed privately-owned diesel generators. An aggregate of 600 to 800 MW of such small, inefficient units are thought to exist. In the absence of firm data, privately-generated electricity is estimated at 1500 GWh annually, giving an average load factor of 21 percent for these generators. These non-utility systems are environmentally unsound and cannot be expected to meet growth in demand. Furthermore, the extensive anarchic distribution networks associated with them are not only unsafe but also an unsightly feature of the urban landscape. In early 1996, after EDL had been able to provide a 24-hour supply service to customers, the owners of these back-up generators set in place to meet the shortfall in EDL's supplies were being persuaded to shut them down. Sector Rehabilitation 1.6 Under the NERP, over US$315 million was spent to rehabilitate generation, transmission and distribution facilities. Works were selected to restore the bulk of pre-war nominal capacity through repair and retrofitting, but did not provide new capacity. Priorities included restoring communication links with the dispatching center; increasing the availability of existing generating stations; reconstructing damaged transmission and distribution facilities; restoring public safety; and protecting existing equipment from further damage. On completion of these works, it is expected that 24-hour public supply would be provided to almost all regions. However, rehabilitated capacity (1,200 MW) will not be sufficient to meet peak load, even with imports from Syria. System reliability will continue to be inadequate and rationing unavoidable pending commissioning of new generation in 1997.
 Power Sector Restructuring and Transmission Expansion Project 3 Re-establishing Financial Viability: Steps Undertaken and the Challenges Ahead 1.7 EDL has incurred losses for many years. Financial difficulties result from high technical and non-technical losses, including those resulting from widespread illegal connections, coupled with loss of control over its commercial operations, and low tariffs. In 1995, technical and non-technical losses accounted for nearly 60 percent of production instead of a normal 10 to 12 percent for a comparable system. The Government of Lebanon (GOL) and EDL are aware that tariffs need to be adjusted to reflect costs, but deferred action until a credible plan began implementation to regain mastery of EDL's commercial operations by: substantially reducing non-technical losses; improving collection ratios; and, improving service quality to a level of service continuity of close to 24 hours/day. (The current tariff structure is shown at Annex 1.5). Recently, tariffs were increased when most of the plant being rehabilitated (some 1,100 MW) entered service. Additional steps were taken starting late 1995 to deal vigorously with billing weaknesses and non-technical losses. Turnkey contracts have been let to: (i) verify metering and correctly bill all medium and high voltage customers - a measure that covers 2,000 consumers, accounting for approximately 25 percent of EDL's forecast revenues in 1996; (ii) normalize metering installations for some 140,000 customers in two urban areas where non-technical losses are disproportionately high; and (iii) install a new commercial billing and customer accounting system. In addition, the contracting-out - under performance-based arrangements - of meter reading and revenue collection activities has been let to 18 private agencies covering areas outside of Greater Beirut. Despite these actions, EDL's losses in 1996 are forecasted at near US$150 million. Further tariff increases, financial restructuring, and measures to deal with the systemic problems in commercial operations are urgently required to accelerate the restoration of the sector. Sectoral Strategy/Priority Policy Reform: Restructuring and the Unbundling of EDL 1.8 Consultants (funded by the Bank under the ERRP) recently completed a comprehensive management audit of the sector. Problems identified include a legal framework that is no longer suited to present circumstances; a severely weakened public utility, EDL, that suffers, inter alia, from a lack of management autonomy; acute skill shortages; and weak financial and commercial practices. At the same time, EDL is facing a major challenge in modernizing and expanding all aspects of its operations. The consultants developed a menu of options to re-establish the viability of the sector, lost during the war. Following a consultative process to discuss options and modalities for implementation with key stakeholders, Government decided, in principle, to unbundle the main operational functions of EDL and bring in private management to run generation and distribution. GOL's sectoral reform program is discussed further below. In order to help introduce a competitive power market regulated by an independent regulator with adequate powers, inter alia, to grant licenses and set tariffs and standards, assurances were obtained during negotiations that, not later than January 1, 1998, the Government will submit an appropriate draft electricity law to Parliament. The program is spelled out in detail in the Letter of Sectoral Development Policy (LSDP)3 (Annex 1.3). 2 Effective March 1, 1996, the fixed charge component for all consumer categories was increased from LLI,000/kVA to LL1,200/kVA and a three-part rate with an on-peak charge of US$0.20/kWh was set for large consumers having a demand Ž300 kW.  4 Power Sector Restructuring and Transmission Expansion Project 1.9 The reform program includes: a set of sector-wide restructuring actions designed to introduce competition along with the participation of the private sector in utility operations; and a set of actions to deal with internal reform actions for EDL itself - to re-establish its financial viability and develop its management capacity in line with its newly-defined mandate under the new, unbundled, sector structure. Main elements of the overall reform program include: * unbundling of the vertically integrated national utility into separate production, transmission, and distribution functions; * privatization of these key functional areas in a program involving "affermage"4 and upon approval by Parliament of the new electricity law, the establishment of several privately- operated regional distribution concessions; * restructuring residual utility functions under the restructured EDL which would now serve as an asset holding company (societe de patrimoine) while retaining the natural monopoly functions of sector planning; bulk power contracting; transmission and generation dispatch; * introduction of two new laws: (a) a new sector electricity law; and (b) a new law and statutes covering the restructured EDL. The former law will provide for a competitive power market through the separation of electricity generation, transmission and distribution functions, the participation of the private sector therein, and the establishment of an autonomous regulatory body in the sector; * a vigorous program to dramatically cut non-technical losses (over 40% of production is currently lost due to such causes) and to improve collections; * in harmony with the technical loss reduction and collection improvement program (para. 1.7 above) make effective a series of annual rate increases to achieve sector solvency by year 2000; * phase-out GOL subsidies - now exceeding US$100 million/year - that keep EDL afloat. Interim subsidies for years 1996-99 will be treated as grants until sector solvency is achieved; * establish institutional capacity using a Project Management Team to manage the US$486 million transmission construction program; and * the placement of a US$100 million GOL bond issue backed by the World Bank guarantee facility to support the sector reconstruction and reform program. 1.10 GOL has indicated that sector unbundling will require new legislation. It is expected that a new EDL Law will be submitted to Parliament in 1998 allowing the utility to operate on a commercial basis; and would, inter alia, authorize the lease of assets on a long-term basis to private operators. However, preparation of bidding documents for the leasing contracts is underway. It is important to note that key initial steps of the reform program have already been implemented. Namely: the recapitalization of EDL (US$450 million of GOL debt has been converted to equity); the restoration of the Kadisha concession; and the letting of management contracts to perform meter-reading and collection activities (para 1.7). Affermage or "operational contracting "- a contractual leasing arrangement under which the private operator ("termier") leases state assets, and operates the facilities using his own working capital. Depending on contractual arrangements, new investments needed to operate/expand the leased facilities may be financed by the fermier.
 Power Sector Restructuring and Transmission Expansion Project 5 Sectoral Investment Program 1.11 National reconstruction - following the initial NERP phase - includes very substantial investments in power. The 1995-2002 sectoral investment program is estimated at US$2.2 billion (including physical and price contingencies). Forty-seven percent of the power program is for new generation projects, totaling approximately 1,000 MW, and it provides for the overdue replacement of about 200 MW of non-repairable capacity as well as additions to meet demand growth. Reinforcement of the transmission system accounts for a further 31 percent of the program, while distribution represents 18 percent. Implementation of the program is concentrated in the early years, due to the backlog of investment which could not be carried out during the war. The Government has proceeded with these capacity additions, as it considers them essential to providing utility-quality power supply throughout Lebanon and to be vital for the nation's economic recovery. Rationalefor Bank Involvement 1.12 The proposed Project constitutes a logical follow-up to the emergency rehabilitation of the electricity sector under the ERRP. It is also essential to the satisfactory completion of the power system facilities rehabilitated under the NERP and to assure their sustainability. GOL has requested the support of the Bank to assist it in designing a modern institutional and regulatory framework for the sector and in mobilizing external resources for reconstruction. The former involves a step-by-step process which will take several years to put in place. Without the specialized technical support that the Bank is able to provide, it is likely that the process of institutional renewal would be postponed, putting at risk the entire sector reconstruction effort. The Bank would play a catalytic role in establishing a credible policy environment conducive to the attraction of private sector operators (key to the sustainability of reconstruction of the sector) and in coordinating support from other donors and export credit agencies. Through the support provided by the proposed Project for the implementation of the LSDP Action Program, conditions for efficiency and quality of service improvements would be created, enabling the private sector to play a major role in sector operations and possibly also in future investment. The proposed Project is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy discussed by the Board on June 29, 1994, which calls for Bank support for reconstruction of basic infrastructure and for a private-sector-led economic recovery. 1.13 The proposed Project and underlying policy reforms are consistent with the Bank's guidelines for lending in the power sector. These call for shifting the role of governments from ownership and management to policy-making and regulation, promoting efficiency and quality through commercialization of operational activities and competitive provision of services. Finally, the proposed Project is an essential part of a comprehensive and integrated sector investment program needed to re- establish utility service in the entire country. Absent the timely construction of a reliable backbone transmission system, remaining investments (near US$1.7 billion) now underway in power plants and distribution facilities would not only become redundant, but would result in financial drain on the economy. Lessons from Previous Bank Involvement 1.14 Implementation experience under the ERRP has been good. Institutional development and reform, particularly when it involves legislation, is expected to take a period of several years because of the need to develop political consensus. GOL and EDL are committed to reform, but this must proceed flexibly at its own pace. In this current context, it is more appropriate to agree on a broad framework for reform of the sector, rather than on a set of detailed milestones in an ambitious action program. GOL has

THE BENEFICIARY Legal Framework 2.1 Historically, power supply in Lebanon was entrusted to private concessions, a few of which still exist. EDL, the beneficiary of the proposed loan, is the result of the acquisition by the state in 1954 of a number of private electricity concessions. In its present form, EDL was created under a 1964 decree5 that entrusts it with the generation, transmission and distribution of electricity throughout Lebanon. 2.2 Under the 1964 decree, EDL is constituted as a government-owned company with financial and administrative autonomy and is entitled to operate on a commercial basis. Its Board of Directors has seven members, appointed by the Government. Board powers, spelled out in part in a 1972 decree applicable to all such enterprises,6 are broad and include the formulation of company policy, personnel statutes, as well as the approval of budgets, work programs, tariffs and significant contracts. 2.3 According to the 1972 decree, Board decisions are subject to subsequent approval of the MHER, which exercises the tutelage. Furthermore, a Ministry of Finance (MoF) representative, attends all Board meetings, and, through the Ministry of Finance, approves all significant financial decisions. In recent years, the Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR), which assumed the duties of the Ministry of Planning and took charge of the rehabilitation of Lebanese infrastructure following the war, has entered into contracts well in excess of US$800 million involving new power plants, as well as the rehabilitation of EDL's electrical installations throughout Lebanon. Finally, a number of Government bodies oversee various aspects of EDL's operations. In short, for all practical purposes, parties other than EDL are active in the power sector, and EDL itself enjoys minimal autonomy in all important functional areas. 2.4 The legal framework under which EDL operates has been the subject of a detailed assessment (para. 1.8) which concluded, inter alia, that: (i) it lacked clarity due to a plethora of inconsistent laws and decrees; (ii) its framework was too rigid, and thus was unresponsive to the requirements of a modern power utility; and (iii) it restricted private sector involvement. After a review of viable options, the consultant recommended that the legal framework under which EDL operates be modernized and new statutes enacted. The LSDP provides that a new EDL Law will be submitted to Parliament in 1998 allowing the utility to operate on a commercial basis. The ten senior positions are manned, but many middle-management positions are vacant as there are no suitable candidates within the organization, and external recruitment has been prohibited by GOL. 2.6 EDL has some 3,040 staff, of which two-thirds are regular employees, and while the balance are on temporary status, most have worked in the company for decades. EDL has not been permitted to recruit new staff since 1983, and therefore the average age is high (about 48.3 years). Motivation is low given salary levels, in most cases only slightly above the minimum legal wage in the country. Moreover, as a result of many departures, managers and professionals make up only about 4 percent of the staff, compared to an industry norm of 10 percent. Furthermore, as a result of the restructuring of the sector, there will be inevitable reductions in the number of EDL staff (the majority of the work force affected by the transfer to the private sector would likely be retained by the new operators). In all, redeployment will have to be handled with due sensitivity, fully taking into consideration matters such as retraining, separation benefits, and pension rights. In order to address the issue, a manpower study is expected to be carried out during 1997. 2.7 With respect to training programs, these have to be designed taking into account the manpower profile of the utility, and the plans for the future. In EDL's case, priority has been given to hiring outside expertise, particularly from Electricite de France (EdF), which has been supporting EDL in several areas including project management and the loss reduction program. EDL intends to recruit during 1997 expertise in financial management and in specific technical areas to strengthen its teams and provide on- the-job training to its own personnel. This training strategy is satisfactory. Accounts andAudit 2.8 EDL accounts are maintained in accordance with the French Accounting Code of 1957, and have not yet been adapted to the Lebanese accounting code of 1981. During the war years, accounts were maintained but closure of books occurred long after each accounting period. After significant efforts and with the help of its auditors, heavily qualified accounts were submitted for 1992-95. In addition, provision of electricity to residential consumers by the 'informal sector' was extensive during the war, and continues today, although on a reduced scale. No authoritative data exist on the capacity installed or the energy supplied by private generators. EDL's current losses are estimated to be approximately 54 percent, of which only about 15 percent is due to technical factors. The remainder is attributed to weak commercial and customer management practices. Electricity consumption data by end-use category is very approximate. Until unrestricted 24-hour public supply is achieved and consumer behavior has adapted accordingly, the level of demand can only be surmised. During the past few years, several attempts have been made by EDL and its consultants to prepare demand forecasts. Inevitably, these forecasts cover a wide range: peak load for the year 2000 is in the range of 1,600-1,900 MW, compared to a projected 1996 peak of 1,350 MW. Electricity demand is projected to grow between 6-8 percent annually between 1995-2000, while the current Bank forecast of GDP growth over the same period is 8 percent. During the war there was considerable damage to the power facilities through destruction and lack of maintenance. Many of the generating facilities are now obsolete. Through the National Emergency Reconstruction Program (NERP) about US$295 million has been allocated to cover the most urgent rehabilitation works for generation, transmission and distribution facilities. Works to be included in the NERP were selected to restore pre-war nominal capacity through repair and retrofitting, but not to provide new capacity. Priorities and criteria for the selection of work components included: (I) restoring communication links with the dispatching center; (2) increasing the capacity and availability of the existing generating stations; (3) reconstructing the damaged transmission and distribution facilities; (4) restoring public safety; and (5) protecting existing equipment from further damage. As these works are being completed utility service is improving significantly and is approaching 24-hour service throughout Lebanon.' 2. However, the restored thermal generation capacity of about 1,200 MW still is not sufficient to meet the expected load and extensive rationing would still be needed at peak load if the planned interconnection with Syria had not taken place. The recent interconnection of the Syrian and Lebanese power systems at Deir Nbouh (Nord) has been reestablished and up to 120 MVA can be imported, providing additional relief at peak load. 3. In order to alleviate these deficiencies and to provide the required level of reliable power for the projected load growth, the decision was made to add two 450 MW combined-cycle plants each at Beddawi (IPC) in the north and at Zaharani in the south. In addition to the above, two 70 MW gas turbine generating plants are being installed to back-up regional load centers, one at Tyre in the south and the other at Baalbeck in the Bekaa Valley, and are scheduled to be in service by mid-1996. This will bring the total new installed capacity to 1,040 MW. 4. Electricite de France (EdF), acting as consultants to Electricite du Liban (EDL), carried out transmission planning studies in 1993-94 based on three scenarios: 1,300 MW, 1,500 MW and 2,500 MW. The study considered a number of transmission system reinforcements for effecting the power transfer from the new generating sites to the distribution network. EdF recommended as least-cost the implementation of a new transmission system at 220-kV with appropriate interconnections to the existing underlying lower voltage networks to be capable of meeting an initial demand of 1,500 MW at the 220-kV level. At time of writing two main transmission substations were severely damaged due to military actions, and service availability deteriorated to four hours/day over the entire national territory.

To supply the 1,500 MW demand scenario a new 220-kV transmission network will be implemented, consisting of a main North-South artery tying the sites of Zaharani to the South and IPC to the North with Beirut in the center and further 220-kV interconnections to the south, including the connection of Sour and Saida from Zaharani thus reinforcing the 66-kV transmission in this area. To increase the supply security, a loop of 220-kV will be installed around Beirut, connecting Mkalles, Achrafieh , commercial, ras Beyrouth, Pins and Aramoun by underground cable and Mkalles to Aramoun by 220-kV overhead transmission lines. To the north, the new generation will be connected to the 220-kV system at IPC which will be further connected to Bsalim (via Halate and in the future via Kousba) and to Nord. The connection from IPC to Bahsas will be by two 220-kV underground cable circuits. There is an existing double circuit 220-kV transmission line between IPC and Nord. To insure a power supply with a good voltage profile for the Bekaa Valley area to the East a 220/66-kV substation at Ksara will be installed which will be connected to Nord via Baalbeck and Aramoun by 220-kV transmission lines. To further increase the transmission system security, three 220/150-kV interconnections will be implemented, one in Deir Nbouh, one at Bsalim and the other at Aramoun and in addition, power will be fed to the 66-kV network by four new 220/66-kV substations at IPC, Halate, Sour, Ksara and Zaharani and directly to the distribution system by 11 new 220-kV/MV substations at Baalbeck, Ras Beyrouth, Aramoun, Commercial, IPC, Ksara, Halate, Mkalles, Pins, Saida and Sour in the first stage and Kousba, Bahsas, Achrafieh in the second stage. 6. The 1,500 MW system configuration chosen in the study was modified by EDL due to some physical and financial constraints. Physical modifications included: (1) the inclusion of the second circuit on the transmission lines through the Bekaa Valley while initially operating it at 66-kV, thus allowing the upgrading of the existing 66-kV lines in this area while maintaining the 66-kV supply. When the 66-kV lines are upgraded the second circuit through the Bekaa Valley will operate at 220-kV; (2) the installation of gas insulated switchgear (GIS) substations in urban areas due to the high cost of land and to construct substations that are aesthetically consistent with the urban neighborhoods; and (3) the installation of underground 220-kV cables from IPC to Bahsas due to urban congestion which precludes the installation of 220-kV overhead transmission lines in this location. The financial restraints were essentially the deferral of capital expenditures for underground cables and transformers. This deferral will result in the single contingency requirement not being met until the cables and transformers are installed. On a short-term basis, the deferrals are acceptable, but as the financial condition of EDL improves, the additional underground cables and transformers should be installed in order to meet the single contingency system criteria. 7. The electricity sector in Lebanon is making pioneering efforts to introduce environmental management in its operations. An example is the recent decision to use only higher quality, one-percent sulfur, fuel oil at the Zouk power station, which will contribute significantly to reduce total S02 emissions in Lebanon. There are also plans to further control emissions of SO2 and particulate materials through the environmental upgrading of the existing power plants at Zouk, Jieh and Hrayche. The power sector is presently the major emitter of S02, accounting for about 75 percent of emissions in 1993/94. 2. As part of these efforts, an environmental assessment was carried out for the sector expansion, including two power generation projects, and the transmission system project. This summary will focus on the aspects related to the project proposed for World Bank financing, i.e., the transmission system, including the transmission line, its right-of-way, substations and access or maintenance roads. B. Major Project Components 3. The transmission system project includes 339 km of 220-kV overhead, double- and single-circuit lines, and 49 km of 220-kV underground cables, located around Beirut and Tripoli. It also includes ten 220-kV-150-kV substations, out of which three are extensions of existing substations (Bsalim, Pins and Saida). Due to the limited availability of land and potential environmental constraints, GIS substations are programmed for seven of these sites. 4. To facilitate environmental analysis, the project is divided into four sections: (i) Section 1, located along the coastal zone, comprises the lines from Sour to Tripoli/Beddawi, crossing a densely populated and industrialized area; (ii) Section 2, from Aramoun to Ksara, crosses the Lebanon Mountain range; (iii) Section 3, Ksara to Hermel, follows the Bekaa valley in Eastern Lebanon through mostly agricultural land; and (iv) Section 4, Hermel-Tripoli/Beddawi crosses the mountain range in the North of Lebanon.  Annex 3.7 Page 3 of6 D. Potential Environmental Impacts 9. Land acquisition and use. During the design of the project, effective measures have been adopted to minimize interference with existing settlement and land use. This included the avoidance of designated urban areas (in consultation with local authorities), of existing or proposed industrial estates and regional infrastructure developments, of high value agricultural land and of archaeological, cultural and historical sites. The land use changes due to implantation of the towers will affect about 3.7 ha of agricultural land, 1.2 ha of forest areas and 2.5 ha of grassland with rocky outcrops. These land losses are small in comparison with the ongoing conversions in land use from agriculture to industrial and urban uses. In the easement areas, most of the land will not require any changes from its present land use, due to the adopted design heights and selective location of towers. 10. Landscape/Visual Impacts. The clearance height of 16m requires unusually high towers; hence these towers will be visible from far away against the skyline, especially in exposed hilltops and visible stands. A design review will establish whether it is possible to reduce the height for some route sections (e.g., crossing agricultural land). 11. Vegetation and Wildlife. Vegetation will be affected directly at the tower and substation sites, but recovery after construction is possible, provided that there is erosion control. About 59 km of forested areas will be crossed by the route; most of these forests have already degenerated to machie or garigue with oaks, due to extensive overgrazing. In general, as the traversed woodland is not dense, there is no need for extensive clearance. Transmission lines may affect birds, in particular: birds of prey, ducks and sea birds (along the coast) may be killed by colliding with the conductors. Because of the lack of resting or breeding areas along the route, the effect of the transmission lines on migrating birds might be limited. 12. Protected Areas. The project will not affect any of the three existing protected areas in Lebanon. 13. Water Resources. The transmission line project can be implemented without significant adverse effects on water resources. Direct impacts of the project on surface water will be confined to an increase in the sediment runoff during the construction phase at river crossing locations. No direct negative impacts on groundwater are expected. The availability of electricity at rural locations through the network's extension will probably increase pumping for irrigation, thus affecting water resources in the long term. 14. Noise and Air Quality Transformer cooling Medium. The transmission line project will not contribute to a significant increase on ambient noise levels and to a decrease in air quality. The projected use of GIS substations in urban areas reduces the transformer noise. The transformer oil cooling systems do not utilize PCBs. 15. Electrical and Magnetic Fields. Using the worst case values, the electrical field strength at ground level beneath the 220-kV OTL will attain a maximum of about 3-kV/m, at mid-span between two masts. This is below the guideline value of the International Radiation Protection Association (IRPA)/WHO, which is 5-kV/m. The corresponding magnetic flux density arising in usual operating practice could range between 8 and 30 uT, thus below of the IRPA/WHO guideline value of 200 uT. Based on previous investigations and epidemiological

No direct adverse impacts are expected on these activities, as neither the transmission lines not the substations are located in or near established recreation and tourism sites or related facilities. Visual impacts from the transmission line could negatively affect landscapes of touristic interest, in special the forested gorges north of Beirut, and other forested areas. The transmission lines would contribute positively to the tourism industry, by reducing the frequency of interruptions of the power supply in touristic areas, such as the coastal corridor and the archeological sites in the Bekaa. 17. Historical and Cultural Sites. The transmission line route sections and substation sites have been located in order to avoid built-up areas to the greatest extent possible, with particular attention to registered historical sites. In general, the selected routes and sites are at acceptable distances from existing or possible locations of historical, cultural and archeological sites. Although the discovery of new significant sites during the construction phase is considered remote, measures for the protection of the sites and relics eventually discovered are recommended in the environmental mitigation plan. An economic evaluation of the 1995-99 time-slice of the sectoral investment program (Annex 4.2, Appendix 6) was carried out, rather than for one single element - the expansion of the backbone ring transmission system provided for under the project. This time-slice approach is to deal with what would otherwise be an arbitrary allocation of specific benefits to an element of an investment program, when the entire program itself is required to meet customer demand. Using this approach, only investments in generation, transmission and distribution were included in the analysis. Physical contingencies at a uniform 10 percent were added to base costs. Provision for operating and maintenance costs were taken at 2 percent of the cumulative investment costs. Since the new generating plants are all No. 2 fuel (diesel)-fired, incremental fuel costs were estimated using this fuel at a price of US$170/ton (in constant terms). Average running heat rates (fuel efficiency) of 190 gms/kWh was used for the new 450 MW combined- cycle plants. Demand and Energy Forecasts 2. Two scenarios of electricity demand growth were examined. The first assumes 8 percent annual economic growth, in line with the current Bank GDP forecast for Lebanon. The second is more conservative, and assumes that economic growth will average 6 percent over the 1996- 2000 period. Both scenarios allow for the impact of higher real electricity prices on electricity demand. Normally, economic growth in developing economies results in electricity demand growth at a higher rate than the growth in GDP. However, in the case of Lebanon, given the expected large real price increases and the scope for demand-reducing measures, electricity demand is projected to grow over the planning period 1995-2002 only at a rate equal to the growth in GDP. 3. The base year for the demand forecast was taken as 1995. Estimated consumption was reconstituted for the base year given that 24-hour continuity of supply by EDL had not yet been restored and utility recorded data was incomplete. It was thus necessary to include an estimate of electricity provided by private generators to arrive at an overall power market figure for total electricity consumption in 1995. However, data on the numerous individual private generation suppliers is scarce and unreliable. EDL's consultants (Emst & Young) attempted to quantify the installed capacity held in private hands, either for self-use and/or for resale. E & Y estimate that in 1995 about 600 MW of private generation capacity was used on average for near 7 hours/day, producing 1,500 GWh. Restructuration du secteur electrique au Liban, February 1996.

Of the 1 million tons of diesel imported in 1995, the transport sector was estimated to account for 350-400,000 tons,2 construction and heating for 100,000 tons each, leaving the balance of 450-500,000 tons for power generation. As EDL did not use any diesel fuel for power generation in 1995, most, if not, all of this diesel fuel would have been consumed by private generators. By way of comparison, generating 1,500 GWh using small diesel units would have consumed 450,000 tons of fuel, assuming an average efficiency of 300 gms/kWh. The estimate of 1,500 GWh for informal supplies thus appears reasonable, and was added to EDL's production of 5,422 GWh to give a total estimate of the 1995 national power market of 6,922 GWh, which served as a base for the demand projections. The main quantifiable benefit from the investment program is the incremental energy supplied to consumers as a result of the sector investment program. The first generation units are due in service in 1997. Hence the incremental electricity consumption over the five years 1997-2001 was considered as the main benefit from the program. However, the prevailing (1996) average tariff of LL 103 (6.4 US cents)/kWh, is well below full-cost recovery and does not reflect the benefits to consumers of utility-grade electricity supply. In Lebanon, the willingness of residential consumers to pay high rates for minimal, low-quality electricity supply has been clearly demonstrated. The informal sector generators charge between US$30-45 per kVA on a monthly basis for supply varying between 8 and 12 hours per day. This is equivalent to an average of LL 200(13 US cents)/kWh. The impact of valuing the benefits at the tariffs projected to be applied if the proposed loan conditions are fulfilled would yield an IRR of 17.2 percent. doc.abstracts: The objectives of this Power Sector Restructuring and Transmission Expansion Project are to: a) expand the high voltage transmission system to meet an integrated system peak demand of approximately 1,500 MW at the N-1 level of reliability; and b) to assist the borrower in implementing the action program in the Letter of Sectoral Development Policy (LSDP) which provides for establishing an enabling environment for private sector involvement in the power section, including the institutional restructuring of the sector. The project comprises two elements: a) an investment component which will include double and single circuit 220-kV transmission lines, underground 220-kV cables and new 220-kV substations; and b) an institutional development component consisting of technical assistance for project implementation, training, and assistance to implement the institutional reform action program defined in the Government's LSDP.
